data.title: Git icon keeps refreshing when 2 projects open sharing git parent

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.12.0-insider (0bec115779b11a9d78bdb24ad7918c22524ea2ac, 2017-04-28T18:57:52.518Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|path-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.2.0|
|gitignore|codezombiech|0.5.0|
|bracket-pair-colorizer|CoenraadS|0.10.3|
|tslint|eg2|0.12.0|
|vscode-postfix-ts|ipatalas|1.3.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

Have a folder setup like the following:

- Project
    - .git
    - Server
    - Client

1. Open 1 VSCode instance on Server folder
2. Open another VSCode instance on Client folder
3. Git icon keeps blinking the blue clock icon every 5 seconds in both VSCode instances

I guess they are triggering each other somehow, even if there are no changes.  
Its pretty distracting, as a workaround I removed git from the activity bar and use command line.

data.title: Request: Ability to write snippets in yaml.
data.body:
Hi there. I searched the issue history for this repo and wasn't able to find this. Please forgive me if it already exists!

This is just a friendly request for the suggestion box: Currently, we are only able to write snippets in json5. It would be nice to have the ability to write them in yaml to make adding and arranging snippets easier.

Wouldn't it be possible to load snippets in the same way as they are currently, but if `.yml`, `.yaml` files are found, just run them through a yaml parser (e.g. [`js-yaml`](https://github.com/nodeca/js-yaml)) prior to consuming in vscode? 

Thanks for considering! 😄

data.title: Docblock editor not expanding when asterisk is not preceded by a space.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a docblock like this:
```
/**
* Test<cursor here>
*/
```
2. Hit enter and the result will be:
```
/**
* Test<cursor here>

*/
```

If the asterisk on that line had a space before it, it would have been expanded, but that's not always the case.

data.title: [Feature Request] Allow auto-close quotation marks per file type and global

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.0 - insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

-- Sorry for the English, I used Google Translator --

After a [long conversation](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/19515#issuecomment-297827062) with @alexandrudima the same suggested that he open that issue.
@alexandrudima, I do not know if that's what you imagined .. so feel free to edit.

By default all single and double quotation marks should auto close if you have `words + space`.
By default all single and double quotation marks should not close if it is next to the `word`. For single quotes should be considered apostrophe.

Here are examples of how to share the quotes. Similiar to Atom and Sublime.

Eg1:
![ex1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19866231/25551034/91decc26-2c55-11e7-8fa5-ebfb14e9ba40.gif)


Eg2:
![ex2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19866231/25551036/9756190c-2c55-11e7-8914-b9053f506301.gif)


Allow the same to be set up separately for comments. (This is the javascript that auto closes single quotation marks in code, but not when used in comments.) By default it should follow the above rules.

There may be a question of syntactic and semantic, depending on the language. So let the resource by language.

There are still letters that allow you to have apostrophes along with single quotes. It does not interfere with semantics and maintains syntax highlighting.

data.title: If there are more than one c++ files having the same file name under different folders, setting break point (gdb backend) in one of them may fail.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: all
- OS Version: ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Attach to a running process (gdb backend).
2. Set break point by left click on the beginning of a code line.
3. The expected break point may be disabled (hallow red circle appears).
4. Another file with the same file name may be affected by this action and it seems that the break point I just set was applied to this file instead.

data.title: Windows Narrator: Inappropriate announcement for text in "select additional" window while installing Visual Studio code.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Win10 1703 (Build 15063.138)

**Steps to reproduce:**
1.Download and Run Visual studio code
2.Navigate to "Select Additional " window.
3.Observe narrator behavior for "Additional icons " text and "other" text

**Actual Result:**
Narrator is announcing as editable text with "0" as value for "Additional icons " text and "other" text. 

NVDA Behavior:
NVDA is not announcing as Editable text.

**Expected Result:**
Narrator should not announce as editable text with "0" as value for "Additional icons " text and "other" text. 

**User Impact:**
users who rely on screen reader will get confused if narrator is reading as editable text.

data.title: Debugger does not support "Move to line"

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.x
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04
- Language: C++
- Debugger: gdb

The VSCode debugger interface does not allow the user to update the current PC (Program Counter) to a specific line in a function.  This is very useful, especially when you want skip certain instructions or re-run a function you accidentally stepped over.

data.title: Single step in debugger collapses all variables being watched
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.x
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04
- Language: C++
- Debugger: gdb

When stepping over an instruction, any expanded variables in the watch window are automatically collapsed, force the user to to expand any variable of interest to view it's contents.  This is particularly annoying when you need to observe how a nested variable (2 or more levels deep) is updated across several lines of code.

data.title: Feature request: Remember UI state for search panel
data.body:
Whenever I open VSCode or I open a new window, and I do a search, I have to:

* Click the little arrow to make sure the "replace" field is shown
* Enable regular expressions
* Click the little arrow to make sure the file include/exclude fields are shown

These settings together are my "default" settings that I rely on all the time. It's annoying when they're not all available, so I want every search panel to always be set up like this. But these settings don't seem to persist:

* Across restarts
* In new windows
* Across existing windows (so if I change the setting in one window, other windows aren't affected)

I use all three features quite a lot, and hiding them behind little arrows and buttons isn't so great, especially since there's no keyboard shortcut to do any of them without some awkward tab-navigation. But it would be okay if these settings were simply remembered across windows and restarts.

It's a bit nonsensical that the settings are per-window, too. If I have several projects open and search in project A, there's no reason that when I go to project B that I wouldn't want these settings remembered.

---

As an aside, some of the lack of UX elegance here could be improved simply by, for example:

* Making regular expressions the default; pretty much every other search tool out there (grep, ack, ag, ripgrep, etc.) default to regexps, so why not VSCode?
* Always showing the replace field. Sublime and Atom do this, simply because replacing is a very, very common operation.
* Always showing the include/exclude box, but move them to the bottom of the view so they don't clutter the UI.
* Hiding the "files excluded through settings" field, which is arguably only useful when you have issues with the exclusions and could even be moved into the tooltip for the exclude button, since it's purely information and not editable.

Some visual clutter could also be reduced by removing the counts. Do we really need to know that the search hit "6 results in 3 files"?

data.title: Grunt task detection fails silently when grunt is not installed locally
data.body:
Testing #25516

- Have a gruntfile
- If grunt is not installed globally, an error message will tell you to install it. But if grunt is not installed locally, it will just produce a tasks.json with no tasks.

data.title: Question: Plugin for PHP class auto-use?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I'm looking for a plugin for VSC that does what [SublimePHPCompanion](https://github.com/erichard/SublimePHPCompanion) does:

> ### find_use
> 
> Just bring your cursor hover a class name, hit the F5 key (personal shortcut) and that's it.
> 
> It will show you the different namespace that match your class, pick up one and you're done.

Hover over PHP class name, hit shortkey and get namespaced `use`.

Is there any plugin that can do that in VSC?

data.title: Keyboard Shortcut incorrect on British keyboard
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: 10.11.6
- MacBook Pro using built-in British keyboard layout - no external keyboard.

Steps to Reproduce:

**Note**: You'll need a mac with a British keyboard layout for the below scenario 

1. Open the Keyboard Shortcut Panel  `⌘K ⌘S`
2. Search for Terminal in the list of shortcuts
3. The keyboard shortcut displayed is ``⌃` ``

**Note**: this shortcut combination will not open the terminal.

4. Hover on the terminal command in the keyboards shortcut list and click the pen symbol to the left to edit the entry.
5. On a British keyboard press the key combination `` ⌃` `` to set the shortcut combination

**Note**: The symbols displayed in the popup are ``⌃§`` ( ctrl+[IntlBackslash] ) which is on a different key on a British keyboard. The IntlBackslash key is located to the left of the number one on the main keyboard.

data.title: Resizing Bottom Panel Does Not Trigger Request For New Code Lenses
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12 insiders
- OS Version: MacOS 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open the output panel and increase its height so that it takes up most of the screen
2. Set `"typescript.referencesCodeLens.enabled": true`
3. Load a new TS file and scroll so the top of a class is visible. Wait a moment for reference code lenses to be drawn. 
4. Shorten the output panel so that new properties or methods are showing on the class.

**Bug**
Even after resizing stops, code lenses are not shown for the newly revealed code:


![apr-28-2017 13-47-50](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/25546783/6f342040-2c19-11e7-9585-d6a26705a293.gif)

I confirmed that the TS extension's code lens provider is not invoked in this case either

Only after slightly scrolling the editor do the code lenses show up

data.title: Error: Illegal value * for `lineNumber`
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: Current insiders
- OS Version: Mac OS 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

Sorry for the imprecise repo steps. Here's how i've reproduced the issue a few times:

1. Open `diffEditorWidget` in the vscode codebase
2. Copy some text towards the bottom of the file
3. Select all and delete the entire file's contents.
4. Paste the copied text a few times

**Bug**
The editor locks up and I see this error printed to the console

```
Illegal value 3963 for `lineNumber`: Error: Illegal value 3963 for `lineNumber`
    at t.e.getLineMaxColumn (file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/electron-browser/workbench.main.js:28:904092)
    at e.getViewLineMaxColumn (file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/electron-browser/workbench.main.js:28:653128)
    at e.getViewLineMaxColumn (file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/electron-browser/workbench.main.js:28:663349)
    at t.getLineMaxColumn (file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/electron-browser/workbench.main.js:28:683969)
    at t.fromEditorSelection (file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/electron-browser/workbench.main.js:28:410539)
    at o._writePlaceholderAndSelectTextArea (file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/electron-browser/workbench.main.js:28:418782)
    at o.focusTextArea (file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/electron-browser/workbench.main.js:28:418515)
    at t.focusTextArea (file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/electron-browser/workbench.main.js:28:1301401)
    at t.focus (file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/electron-browser/workbench.main.js:28:1696636)
    at t.focus (file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/electron-browser/workbench.main.js:28:1703710)
```

**impact**
Marking as important as it locked up the editor when it happens. To recover, you have to close the editor window. Not sure how often this can be hit

data.title: UI Themes: Should Have option/"old base grayscale" UI themes

the users the ability to either use the old grayscale UI for any theme (maybe they didn't like our color choices) or create new themes with the old default colors perhaps named flat UI...

maybe there is already an easy way to do this I don't know about

data.title: C++ highlighting fails detecting quotes like '\"' or single " in comments
data.body:
Using  `'\"' ` in Code will begin highlight all following code as an String literal.

```cpp
void foo()
{
  auto bar =  '\"';
  //this is code but is marked in editor as continued string because \" is interpreted as start of a string

  //this " in a comment is also interpreted as begin or end of a string, instead of ignored because its an comment
}
```

Expect:  formating like in Code box above
Saw:  from \" until " in comment is highlighted as string

Please ask, if it's not clear what I mean, or more information are needed.
---
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.12.0-insider (5590786c2f676ca2aee12b16cd01b4e0ac621984, 2017-04-20T08:39:52.610Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|

|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.11.0|
